title: 108_hr1617
content: The "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" establishes a program to provide grants for projects addressing railroad infrastructure deficiencies to benefit the public by reducing traffic congestion, transportation emissions, energy usage, and improving railroad efficiency. Eligible projects will be determined by the Secretary of Transportation. SEC. 102 of the "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" outlines eligible projects for funding, including track and intermodal yard capacity maintenance, acquiring rights-of-way, improving rail-road crossings, integrating railroad systems, and track construction. Funding cannot be used for operating expenses, rolling stock acquisition, debt payment, or certain construction purposes. SEC. 103 states that projects must be included in specific transportation plans to be funded under this program. SEC. 104 of the "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" requires that at least 20 percent of project costs must be covered by State, local, and non-Federal public sources. SEC. 105 outlines the allocation of funds. SEC. 105 of the "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" allocates funds for grants under the title. 80% of the funds are distributed to States based on a formula considering rail miles, loaded and unloaded rail cars, and grade crossings. The Secretary of Transportation has discretion over 20% of the funds for grants emphasizing projects of national significance with public benefit. SEC. 106 mandates that laborers and mechanics on projects funded under this Act must be paid prevailing wages. SEC. 107 requires at least 10% of funds to be spent on small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. SEC. 108 provides definitions for terms used in the Act. SEC. 108 defines "rail miles" as route miles and "railroad" as various types of rail transportation. SEC. 201 introduces an excise tax on certain train equipment. A 5% tax is imposed on the sale of specified railroad equipment, including locomotives and rolling stock. A separate 5% tax is imposed on the installation of parts or accessories on such equipment within 6 months of it being placed in service, except for replacement parts or accessories. The installation of parts or accessories on specified railroad equipment is subject to a 5% tax, with exceptions for replacement parts or accessories. Installers are secondarily liable for the tax imposed. SEC. 202 imposes a tax on rail transportation of persons or property, with different rates for commuter rail and other cases. The tax is to be paid by the person making the payment. SEC. 4242 outlines regulations for the transportation of property. SEC. 4242 outlines regulations for the transportation of property, including a 1 percent tax on taxable rail transportation of property paid within or outside the United States. The tax applies to payments made to persons engaged in the business of transporting property by rail for hire. The tax is to be paid by the person making the payment subject to tax, except in cases where payments are made outside the United States, in which the tax is to be paid by the person to whom the property is delivered in the United States by the person providing the last segment of the taxable transportation. SEC. 4243 defines terms and provides special rules. The term 'taxable rail transportation' refers to rail travel within the US, excluding mass transit. 'Transportation' includes layover time and deadhead service movement. Special rules apply to payments made outside the US for prepaid orders and tax deductions on refunds for tickets purchased without tax payment. The curr_chunk discusses the payment of taxes under section 4241 for transportation purchased in connection with tickets or orders. If the tax is not paid at the time of transportation payment, the carrier providing the initial segment of transportation in the US is responsible for paying the tax. A clerical amendment is made to the table of subchapters for chapter 33 of the Code. The amendments made by this section regarding the National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund will take effect on October 1, 2003. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, funded by taxes on railroad locomotives, customs duties, fuel taxes, and royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. The funds are available for expenditures to carry out title I. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is available for expenditures to carry out title I of the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is available for expenditures under the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act.
